block.p: Re ''Highway Debris, Long an Eyesore, Grows as Hazard'' (front page, May 11):
Re ''Highway Debris, Long an Eyesore, Grows as Hazard'' (front page, May 11):

Several summers ago, as we returned to New York City from a long weekend at the beach, a boogie board flew off the roof top of the car in front of us. Catching the wind like a sail and snapping the ties that had ''secured'' it, the board came hurtling toward our car, smacked our windshield and by a stroke of good fortune flew over the roof without shattering the glass.
The speed and impact of this projectile were frightening, and it took all of my control not to veer off the highway.

Most Americans use their cars to vacation. As summer approaches, securing gear to be used on holiday should be a priority. Simply tying equipment to a car roof should be prohibited and deemed a traffic offense.
At the very least, bike racks and roof racks with accompanying equipment that can safely secure objects at high-speed travel (ropes, clamps, enclosures) should be a requirement.
